Week ended 5th January, 1918.NAVAL OPERATIONS.Mines have been laid in the Heligoland Bight, and the laying of a defensive minefield North Sea. off the East Coast of England has been completed.The weather has been generally unfavourable for flying, but a number of patrols and Flanders reconnaissances have been carried out from Dunkirk ; also a raid on Ghistelles aerodrome area an(* where 1,548 lbs. of bombs were dropped amongst the sheds and buildings. FranceDuring the period 2nd-15th December, 1917, R.N.A.S. Squadron No. 8 attached to ran the R.F.C in France, has carried out 74 offensive patrols and 138 special operations. Thirteen combats took. place, during which six enemy machines were driven down out of control one of which is believed to have- been destroyed. There were no R.N.A.S. casualties.The transport " Osmanieh " has been sunk, it is believed by mine, off Alexandria. Casualties. She had on board 47 officers, 885 troops, 37 nurses, 45 naval ratings and 128 crew, total 1,142. The casualties, missing or dead, were 1 military officer and 199 other ranks, 7 nurses, 1 naval officer on passage and 6 naval ratings, and 9 of the crew, total 223.The naval hospital ship " Rewa " was torpedoed and sunk on January 4th seven miles from Tintagel. There were 251 naval and 54 military patients and 215 crew on board. All were saved except three Lascars.The armed drifter " Golden Sunset" was sunk by collision with a trawler about six miles east of Portland on January 4th. The crew were saved.The armed whaler " Hirpa " has gone ashore near Buckie (Banff). The crew were saved.The armed whaler No. 868 was torpedoed on January 3rd about 65 miles from Fife Ness. Eight survivors were picked up.Four men have been killed, and 1 officer and 4 men seriously and 6 men slightly injured, on board the patrol boat " P. 60," when attacking a submarine, owing to the premature explosion of a depth charge on striking the water.The Courts of Inquiry consider that the transport " Aragon " and the destroyer " Attack " (reported sunk in last week's Appreciation) were torpedoed, the latter while picking up survivors from the former.ATTACK UPON ENEMY SUBMARINES.During the week 16 to 18 large enemy submarines have been located, about 12 of Submarines which were operating to the South and West of Great Britain, the area of greatest activity operating, again being the Irish Sea and the English Channel. Aberdeen area. It appears that a submarine, after laying a group of mines well to seaward of Aberdeen, operated for a time in the vicinity with torpedo, and then laid the remainder of (C 893) A 2 her mines, close in shore, after the lapse of a period within which it might be expected that we should have diverted convoys in shore, in order to avoid the first group of mines. Russia,The negotiations opened at Petrograd between Russian and German naval officers, to decide the armistice conditions in the Arctic and on the Murman coast, have been broken off, as the Germans refused to accede to the Russian proposals.On December 31st two German warships with Austrian and Turkish troops, accom-panied by submarines, were reported off Odessa, and a further report states that Turkish and Bulgarian naval delegates have arrived at Kief! with a proposal to obtain possession of the Black Sea Fleet and littoral.The Black Sea Fleet has again mutinied at Sevastopol, and it is reported that 60 officers have been murdered and many more arrested. .NAVAL STAFF,10th January, 1918.[Appbmdices.
